case_name: Jagannath Agarwala v. former State of Mayurbhanj and ex-Ruler of Mayurbhanj

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 666 and 667 of 1957 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 666 and 667 of 1957. C. Chatterjee and G. C. Mathur, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the High Court of Orissa was against Jagannath Agarwala who sought to enforce a claim against the former State of Mayurbhanj and the ex-Ruler of Mayurbhanj.

anchor.surface_text: against a judgment of the High Court of Orissa, by Jagannath Agarwala, who sought to enforce a claim he had against the former State of Mayurbhanj and the ex-Ruler of Mayurbhanj.

facts.text: Two petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution for writs of mandamus were dismissed by the High Court of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: They arise out of two petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution, for writs of mandamus, etc., which the High Court of Orissa dismissed by its order under appeal.

facts.text: In the year 1943 the Maharaja of Mayurbhanj entered into an agreement with Jagannath Agarwala for establishing a business for the manufacture of industrial alcohol and essential oils and for purchases of wheat and barley in the Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in the year 1943 the Maharaja, of Mayurbhanj entered into an agreement or arrangement with Jagannath Agarwala for establishing a business for the manufacture of industrial alcohol and essential oils and for purchases of wheat and barley in the Punjab.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 666 of 1957 relates to the establishment of the manufacturing business.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 666 of 1957 relates to the establishment of the manufacturing business, and Civil Appeal No. 667 of 1957, to the purchases of wheat and barley.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 667 of 1957 relates to the purchases of wheat and barley.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 666 of 1957 relates to the establishment of the manufacturing business, and Civil Appeal No. 667 of 1957, to the purchases of wheat and barley.

facts.text: It was agreed that the capital required would be contributed by the parties in equal shares, and that the profit and loss would also be shared equally.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the establishment of the business, the appellant urges that it was agreed that the capital required would be contributed by the parties in equal shares, and that the profit and loss would also be shared equally.

facts.text: As regards the purchases, the appellant was to advance such money as might be required, and the State of Mayurbhanj was to provide necessary permits and facilities for transport.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the purchases, the appellant was to advance such money as might be required, and the State of Mayurbhanj was to provide necessary permits and facilities for transport.

facts.text: The appellant established a factory and started the business.

anchor.surface_text: In furtherance of this agreement, the appellant urges that he established a factory and started the business, but the Maharaja, instead of contributing his share of the capital,

facts.text: The Maharaja asked the appellant to contribute his share of the capital on his behalf, promising to pay him the amount.

anchor.surface_text: but the Maharaja, instead of contributing his share of the capital, asked the appellant to do so on his behalf, promising to pay him the amount.

facts.text: The factory was constructed, and it went into production, but later closed down, suffering a total loss of Rs. 2,80,875-9-3.

anchor.surface_text: The factory was constructed, and, it appears, it went into production, but later closed down, suffering a total loss of Rs. 2,80,875-9-3.

facts.text: In the first case, the claim of the appellant against the Maharaja and the State was Rs. 1,40,400 odd.

anchor.surface_text: In the first case, therefore, the claim of the appellant against the Maharaja and the State was Rs. 1,40,400 odd.

facts.text: The appellant advanced a sum of Rs. 50,000 and also incurred a further expenditure of Rs. 3,741-7-9.

anchor.surface_text: In the second case, the appellant advanced a sum of Rs. 50,000 and also incurred a further expenditure of Rs. 3,741-7-9.

facts.text: The State of Mayurbhanj failed in its promise of procuring the necessary permits and facilities for transport.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Mayurbhanj failed in its promise of procuring the necessary permits and facilities for transport, and the appellant was, therefore, required to sell the foodgrains in the Punjab,

facts.text: The appellant was required to sell the foodgrains in the Punjab, and thus incurred a loss of Rs. 14,844-0-3.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant was, therefore, required to sell the foodgrains in the Punjab, and thus incurred a loss of Rs. 14,844-0-3.

facts.text: The Maharaja promised to pay the amount.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleges that the Maharaja promised to pay the amount.

facts.text: From January 1, 1949, the Mayurbhanj State merged with the Province of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: From January 1, 1949, the Mayurbhanj State merged with the Province of Orissa, and on the same day, the Government of Orissa promulgated the Administration of Mayurbhanj State Order, 1949

facts.text: Government of Orissa promulgated the Administration of Mayurbhanj State Order, 1949 under s. 4 of the Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947 on January 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day, the Government of Orissa promulgated the Administration of Mayurbhanj State Order, 1949 under s. 4 of the Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947  47 of 1947 .

facts.text: The appellant preferred his two claims for consideration of the Claims Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred his two claims for the consideration of the Claims Officer, who was dealing with such claims on behalf of the Administrator.

facts.text: Claims Officer made a report to the Administrator on June 20, 1951 in respect of the first claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Claims Officer made a report to the Administrator on June 20, 1951 in respect of the first claim, and after examining the merits, gave his conclusions as follows

facts.text: Claims Officer found that the claimant is entitled to a sum of Rs. 1,37,785-13-7-1/2 plus interest at 4% per annum from 1-4-43 to 28-2-49 and thereafter till repayment.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the evidence laid by the Claimant before me in support of his claim, I find that he is entitled to a sum of Rs. 1,37,785-13-7- 1/2. It has been urged by the Claimant that interest Rs. 4 per cent.

facts.text: Claims Officer made a report on November 5, 1951 that the appellant had substantiated his claim for Rs. 14,844-0-3, and was also liable to be paid interest amounting to Rs. 5,303-14-0.

anchor.surface_text: In the other case, he made a report on November 5, 1951 that the appellant had substantiated his claim for Rs. 14,844-0- 3, and was also liable to be paid interest amounting to Rs. 5,303-14-0.

facts.text: On June 28, 1952, the appellant received a Memorandum from the Deputy Secretary, Board of Revenue, Orissa, rejecting the claims as barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: On June 28, 1952, the appellant received a Memo randum from the Deputy Secretary, Board of Revenue, Orissa, Cuttack, which read as follows Dear Sri Agarwalla, With reference to your petitions dated 1-10-51 and 7-9-50.

facts.text: The appellant applied for review.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellant applied for review, and he was asked on November 8, 1952 to produce before the Board any document or documents in his possession

facts.text: On November 8, 1952 the appellant was asked to produce documents to show continuing businesses and point out law on limitation.

anchor.surface_text: and he was asked on November 8, 1952 to produce before the Board any document or documents in his possession to show that these were continuing businesses and also to point out the law that no claim of a continuing business could be barred by limitation.

facts.text: On April 2, 1953, the solicitors of the appellant were informed that the Board of Revenue had declined to review the matter.

anchor.surface_text: but on April 2, 1953, the solicitors of the appellant were informed that the Board of Revenue had declined to review the matter.

facts.text: Even before the merger the Revenue Minister, Mayurbhanj State, rejected the claim by order dated October 26, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It appears also that, in the first case, even before the merger the Revenue Minister, Mayurbhanj State, had rejected the claim put forward by the appellant by his order dated October 26, 1948,

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the two petitions under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: It was in these circumstances, that the two petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution were filed. The High Court dismissed them.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on March 8, 1961 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 8. The judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-These two appeals raise a common question of law, and it is convenient to deal with them together.

facts.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the appeals fail, and are dismissed.

the Government of Orissa promulgated the Administration of Mayurbhanj State Order, 1949 under s. 4 of the Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947  47 of 1947 . That Order allowed claims against the State of Mayurbhanj to be preferred to Government for its companysideration.

concepts.unlisted_description: Enables promulgation of orders for administration of extra-provincial states

anchor.surface_text: Clause 9 of the Order, in so far as it is material, is as follows Claims against Ruler of the State.  a  The Administrator shall as soon as possible publish a numberification in the Gazette in English and in vernacular calling upon all persons having pecuniary claims, whether immediately enforceable or number, against the State or the Ruler of the State in his capacity as Ruler of that State, to numberify the same in writing to the officer authorised, by the Administrator in this behalf  hereinafter called the said officer  within three months from the date of the numberification. The numberice shall also be published at such places and in such other manner as the Administrator may by special or general order direct. Every such claimant shall, within the period specified in sub-paragraph  a  numberify to the said officer in writing his claim. with full particulars thereof and any claim presented after the expiration of such period shall be summarily rejected.

concepts.interpretation: Provides procedure for notifying, submitting, inquiring into, and finally deciding claims against the former state and ruler; decision final, no court jurisdiction; applies to claims before 1 Jan 1949

issues.text: Whether the decision of the Claims Officer should have gone to the Board of Revenue as a whole and not to a single Member

anchor.surface_text: The first was that the decision of the Claims Officer should have gone to the Board of Revenue as a whole and not to a single Member and the second was that the appellant should have been served with a notice by the Board before the recommendations of the Claims Officer were rejected, and, as has now

issues.text: Whether the appellant should have been served with a notice by the Board before the recommendations of the Claims Officer were rejected, and allowed a hearing

anchor.surface_text: and the second was that the appellant should have been served with a notice by the Board before the recommendations of the Claims Officer were rejected, and, as has now been argued before this Court, allowed a hearing. The first point was not argued before us, and it seems that the appellant has accepted the decision of the High Court that the Third Member was competent to hear and dispose of these cases.

issues.text: Whether the rejection of the claim was an act of State such that the new Sovereign State could not be compelled by municipal courts to accept the liability of the old Ruler

anchor.surface_text: In reply, Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri contended that the rejection of the claim was an act of State, and that the new Sovereign State could not be compelled by a process of the municipal courts to accept a liability of the old Ruler,

issues.text: What is an act of State and when it ceases to apply between a new Sovereign and the subjects of a State conquered, acquired or ceded to the new Sovereign

anchor.surface_text: What is an act of State and when it ceases to apply between a new Sovereign and the subjects of a State conquered, acquired or ceded to the new Sovereign, has been the subject of several decisions of this Court. In M/s. Dalmia Dadri Cement Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income- tax and The State of Saurashtra v. Memon Haji Ismail Haji, it has been held that unless the new Sovereign, either expressly or impliedly admits the claim., the municipal courts have no jurisdiction in the matter.

issues.text: Whether the act of State comes to an end when claims are invited under the Order or upon a favourable report by the Claims Officer

anchor.surface_text: though the new Sovereign State might make such enquiry as it chose, it was not compelled to give a hearing to the claimant. In his rejoinder, Mr.Chatterjee contended that the act of State was over, when the new Sovereign State invited claims under a law passed for the purpose, and proceeded to consider the evidence tendered in support of the claim He also contended that by the admission of the claim by the Claims Officer the act of State was over,

issues.text: Whether the appellant had a right to be heard within the four corners of the Order before rejection

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee contended that at least within the four corners of the Order, the appellant had a right to be heard, and that he did not have a proper hearing. If the Member, Board of Revenue, entertained some doubt about the claim being within time, he might have heard the party.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can the investigation of claims be said to have conferred a civil right upon the claimants to enforce their claims against the State. In our opinion, enquiry was for the benefit of the State and not for conferring rights upon likely claimants.

anchor.surface_text: On June 28, 1952, the appellant received a Memorandum from the Deputy Secretary, Board of Revenue, Orissa, Cuttack, which read as follows Dear Sri Agarwalla, With reference to your petitions dated 1-10-51 and 7-9-50. I am directed to say that the claims have been rejected as Government have been advised that they are barred by limitation.

arguments.court_reasoning: Merits not examined due to act of State

anchor.surface_text: and he was asked on November 8, 1952 to produce before the Board any document or documents in his possession to show that these were continuing businesses and also to point out the law that no claim of a continuing business could be barred by limitation.

arguments.court_reasoning: Jurisdiction lacking due to act of State

holdings.text: unless the new Sovereign, either expressly or impliedly admits the claim, the municipal courts have no jurisdiction in the matter.

anchor.surface_text: What is an act of State and when it ceases to apply between a new Sovereign and the subjects of a State conquered, acquired or ceded to the new Sovereign, has been the subject of several decisions of this Court. In M/s. Dalmia Dadri Cement Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income- tax and The State of Saurashtra v. Memon Haji Ismail Haji, it has been held that unless the new Sovereign, either expressly or impliedly admits the claim., the municipal courts have no jurisdiction in the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedents in Dalmia Dadri Cement and State of Saurashtra cases.

holdings.text: claims were being asked to be entertained only for investigation and not for acceptance. It is the acceptance of the claim which would have bound the new Sovereign State and the act of State would then have come to an end.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the Order, which was made under the Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, that claims were being asked to be entertained only for investigation and not for acceptance. It is the acceptance of the claim which would have bound the new Sovereign State

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of the Order under Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act.

holdings.text: the act of State could not be said to have come to an end, when the Government allowed claims to be preferred, or when their own Officer made his report.

anchor.surface_text: It would, therefore, appear that the act of State could not be said to have come to an end, when the Government allowed claims to be preferred, or when their own Officer made his report. The Claims Officer was not a part of the municipal courts, and Government cannot be said to have submitted itself to the jurisdiction of the municipal courts,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of precedents including Vaje Singh case where long enquiries did not end act of State.

holdings.text: Nor can the investigation of claims be said to have conferred a civil right upon the claimants to enforce their claims against the State. In our opinion, enquiry was for the benefit of the State and not for conferring rights upon likely claimants.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can the investigation of claims be said to have conferred a civil right upon the claimants to enforce their claims against the State. In our opinion, enquiry was for the benefit of the State and not for conferring rights upon likely claimants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of the enquiry under Clause 9 for State's benefit only.

holdings.text: till there was an acceptance by the Government or some officer of the Government, who could be said to bind the Government, the act of State was still open, and, in our opinion, it was so exercised in this case.

anchor.surface_text: Equally, therefore, the Government had the paramount right to reject a claim, which its Claims Officer considered good but on which the Government held a different opinion. In short, till there was an acceptance by the Government or some officer of the Government, who could be said to bind the Government, the act of State was still open,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No admission or acceptance occurred despite Claims Officer report.

holdings.text: Whether the Member, Board of Revenue should have gone further and given a viva voce hearing was a matter entirely for that Officer to choose, and there was nothing under the law to compel him.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee contended that at least within the four corners of the Order, the appellant had a right to be heard, and that he did not have a proper hearing. If the Member, Board of Revenue, entertained some doubt about the claim being within time, he might have heard the party. That this was an enquiry mainly to ascertain whether a claim should or should not be recognised is obvious enough.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry not judicial trial; prior hearing by Claims Officer and document opportunity sufficient; no mandatory viva voce under Order.

holdings.text: Though we think that such an opportunity might have been afforded to the appellant, we cannot say that this was a matter which entitled him to a writ.

anchor.surface_text: To judge such an action with the same rigour with which a judicial enquiry or trial is judged is to convert the enquiry into a civil suit. The appellant was fully heard by the Claims Officer, and the only question was whether the claim was within time. Even there, the Member, Board of Revenue, asked the appellant to submit all documents and arguments in support of his contention that the claim was within limitation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No breach of natural justice warranting writ under Art. 226.

holdings.text: In this view of the matter, the appeals fail, and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the appeals fail, and are dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Due to lack of jurisdiction on act of State grounds.

anchor.surface_text: What is an act of State and when it ceases to apply between a new Sovereign and the subjects of a State conquered, acquired or ceded to the new Sovereign, has been the subject of several decisions of this Court. In M/s. Dalmia Dadri Cement Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income- tax and The State of Saurashtra v. Memon Haji Ismail Haji, it has been held that unless the new Sovereign, either expressly or impliedly admits the claim., the municipal courts have no jurisdiction in the matter.
In this view of the matter, the appeals fail, and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the Order, which was made under the Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, that claims were being asked to be entertained only for investigation and not for acceptance. It is the acceptance of the claim which would have bound the new Sovereign State
In this view of the matter, the appeals fail, and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It would, therefore, appear that the act of State could not be said to have come to an end, when the Government allowed claims to be preferred, or when their own Officer made his report. The Claims Officer was not a part of the municipal courts, and Government cannot be said to have submitted itself to the jurisdiction of the municipal courts,
In this view of the matter, the appeals fail, and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can the investigation of claims be said to have conferred a civil right upon the claimants to enforce their claims against the State. In our opinion, enquiry was for the benefit of the State and not for conferring rights upon likely claimants.
In this view of the matter, the appeals fail, and are dismissed.

Equally, therefore, the Government had the paramount right to reject a claim, which its Claims Officer considered good but on which the Government held a different opinion. In short, till there was an acceptance by the Government or some officer of the Government, who could be said to bind the Government, the act of State was still open,

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee contended that at least within the four corners of the Order, the appellant had a right to be heard, and that he did not have a proper hearing. If the Member, Board of Revenue, entertained some doubt about the claim being within time, he might have heard the party. That this was an enquiry mainly to ascertain whether a claim should or should not be recognised is obvious enough.
to companyvert the enquiry into a civil suit. The appellant was fully heard by the Claims Officer, and the only question was whether the claim was wi

anchor.surface_text: To judge such an action with the same rigour with which a judicial enquiry or trial is judged is to convert the enquiry into a civil suit. The appellant was fully heard by the Claims Officer, and the only question was whether the claim was within time. Even there, the Member, Board of Revenue, asked the appellant to submit all documents and arguments in support of his contention that the claim was within limitation,
In this view of the matter, the appeals fail, and are dismissed.
